\author {Saharon Shelah}
\address{Einstein Institute of Mathematics\\

Jerusalem, 91904, Israel\\
 and \\
 Department of Mathematics\\

 Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey \\
 110 Frelinghuysen Road \\
 Piscataway, NJ 08854-8019 USA}
\email{shelah@math.huji.ac.il}

  First typed February 26, 2014. Paper 1064}

\subjclass[2010]{Primary: 03C20; Secondary: 03C45,03C75}

\keywords {model theory, set theory, reduced power, saturation,
  classification theory, ${\rm SOP}_3,{\rm SOP}_2$}


 
\date {September 28, 2015}

\begin{abstract}
Our aim was to generalize some theorems about the saturation 
of ultra-powers to reduced powers.  Naturally, we deal via saturation
for types consisting of atomic formulas.  We succeed to generalize
``the theory of dense linear is maximal and so is any
${\rm pair}\,(T,\Delta)$ which is ${\rm SOP}_3$ ($\Delta$ consists of atomic or
conjunction of atomic formulas).  However, ${\rm SOP}_2$ is not enough, so
the ${\mathfrak p} = {\mathfrak t}$ theorem cannot be generalized in this case.  Similarly the
unique dual of cofinality.
\end{abstract}

\maketitle
\numberwithin{equation}{section}

\S0 \quad Introduction, (labels x,z), pg.\pageref{intro}
\bigskip

\noindent
\S1 \quad Axiomatizing \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:c}, (label h), pg. \pageref{1}
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[${{}}$]  [We phrase and prove a theorem which 
axiomatize \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:c}.  
The theorem there says that if $D$ is a regular ultrafilter
  on $I$ and for every model $M$ of the theory of dense linear orders,
the model $M^I/D$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated, then $D$ is $\lambda^+$-good and
$\lambda$-regular.] 
\end{enumerate}
\bigskip

\noindent
\S2 \quad Applying the axiomatized frame, (label c), pg.\pageref{2}
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[${{}}$]  [The axiomatization in \S1 can be phrased as a set of
sentences, surprisingly moreover Horn ones (first order if $\theta_{\bold r} =
  \aleph_0$).  Now in this case we can straightforwardly derive
 \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:a}.  But because the axiomatization being Horn,
 we can now deal also with the ($\lambda^+$,atomic)-saturation of
 reduced power.  We then deal with infinitary logics and comments on models
 of Bounded Peano Arithmetic.]
\end{enumerate}
\bigskip

\noindent
\S3 \quad Criterion for atomic saturation of reduced powers, 
(label g), pg.\pageref{3}
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[${{}}$]  [For a complete first order $T$ we characterize when a
  filter $D$ on $I$ is such that $M^I/D$ is
($\lambda$,atomically)-saturated for every model $M$ of $T$.]
\end{enumerate}
\bigskip

{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[${{}}$]  [We prove that for reduced powers, the parallel of ${\mathfrak t}
  \le {\mathfrak p}$ in general fails, similarly the uniqueness of the dual cofinality.]

(label g,r), pg.\pageref{5}
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[${{}}$]  [We define and prove the results on morality from the
  ultra-filter case to the filter case.  By this we prove that some
  ${\rm SOP}_2$ pair are not $\trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}$-maximal (unlike the
  ultra-filter cases, see \ref{s31}).
\end{enumerate}

\section {Introduction} \label{intro}
\bigskip

\subsection {Background, Questions and Answers} \
\bigskip

We know much on saturation of ultrapowers, but considerably 
less on reduced powers.  For
transparency, let $T$ denote a first order complete countable theory with
elimination of quantifiers and $M$ will denote a model of $T$.  For
$D$ a regular filter on $\lambda > \aleph_0$ we may ask: when $M^\lambda/D$
is saturated?  For $D$ an ultrafilter, Keisler \cite{Ke65} proves that
this holds for every $T$ iff $D$ is $\lambda^+$-good iff this holds
for $T=$ theory of Boolean algebras, such $T$ is called
$\trianglelefteq_\lambda$-maximal.

By \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:a} the maximality holds for $T=$ theory of dense
linear orders or just any $T$ with the strict order property 
and by \cite{Sh:500}, any $T$ with the ${\rm SOP}_3$ is
$\trianglelefteq_\lambda$-maximal.

What about reduced powers for $\lambda$-regular filter $D$ on
$\lambda$?   By \cite{Sh:17}, $M^\lambda/D$ is
$\lambda^+$-saturated for every $T$ {\underline{iff}} \, $D$ is $\lambda^+$-good
and ${\mathscr P}(\lambda)/D$ is a $\lambda^+$-saturated Boolean Algebra.  
Parallel results hold when we replace $\lambda^+$-saturated by
$(\lambda^+,\Sigma_{1+n}({\mathbb L}_{\tau(T)}))$-saturated.  We 
shall concentrate on ($\lambda^+$,atomically)-saturated and the
related partial
order $\trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_\lambda$, see definitions below.

Concerning ultra-powers, lately Malliaris-Shelah \cite{MiSh:998} proves
that $T$ being ${\rm SOP}_2$ suffice for $\triangleleft_\lambda$-maximality
(and that ${\mathfrak t} = {\mathfrak p}$) and, in later work \cite{MiSh:1051}, that 
at least for a relative
$\triangleleft^*_\lambda$ (see \cite{Sh:500}) this is ``iff".  Part of
the proof is axiomatized by Malliaris-Shelah \cite{MiSh:1070}.

Note also that \cite{Sh:1019} deals with saturation but only for
ultra-powers by $\theta$-complete ultrafilters for 
$\theta$ a compact cardinal; and also with $\omega$-ultra-limits.

Now what do we accomplish here?

First, in \S1 we axiomatize the proof of \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:a},
i.e. we define when $\bold r = (M,\Delta)$ is an RSP and for it prove
that the relevant model $N_{\bold r}$ is $(\min\{{\mathfrak p}_{\bold
  r},{\mathfrak t}_{\bold r}\},\Delta)$-saturated.  Second, in \S2 we prove, of
course, that \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:a} follows, but also we show that the
axiomatization of RSP is by Horn sentences.  Hence we can apply it to reduced
powers.  So $T$ is
$\trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_\lambda$-maximal if $T={\rm Th}({\mathbb Q},<)$ and for $T$
having the ${\rm SOP}_3$; lastly we comment on models of Peano Arithemetic.

In \S3 we try to sort out when for models of $T$ we get the relevant
atomic saturation.

Can we generalize also results \cite{MiSh:998} to reduced powers?  
The main result of \S4 says that no.  We also sort out the 
parallel of goodness, excellency and morality for filters 
and atomic saturation for reduced powers.  In hopeful continuation, we consider
parallel statements for infinite logics (see \cite{Sh:1019}); also
we consider non-maximality.
\bigskip

\noindent
Note that by \ref{c31}
\begin{conclusion}
\label{x0}
If $(T,\Delta)$ has the ${\rm SOP}_3$, {\underline{then}}\, it is
$\trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_\lambda$-maximal. 
\end{conclusion}

\begin{question}
\label{x1}
Do we have:  if $D$ is $(\lambda_2,T)$-good and regular {\underline{then}} \, $D$ is
$(\lambda_1,T)$-good when $\lambda_1 < \lambda_2$ (or more).
\end{question}
\bigskip

\subsection {Further Questions}\
\bigskip

\begin{convention}
\label{x2}
1) Let $T$ be a theory with elimination of quantifiers if not said
otherwise.  Let ${\rm Mod}_T$ be the class of models of $T$.

\noindent
2) The main case is for $T$ is a countable complete first
order theory with elimination of quantifiers, moreover, with every
formula equivalent to an atomic one.
\end{convention}
\bigskip

\noindent
So it is natural to ask
\begin{conjecture}
\label{x5}
$(T,\Delta)$ is $\trianglelefteq_{{\rm rp}}$-maximal iff $(T,\Delta)$ 
has the ${\rm SOP}_3$.
\end{conjecture}

So which $T$ (with elimination of quantifiers) are maximal under
$\triangleleft^{{\rm rp}}_\lambda$?  That is, when for every regular filter
$D$ on $\lambda,M^\lambda/D$ is ($\lambda^+$, atomically)-saturated iff
$D$ is $\lambda^+$-good?  Is $T_{{\rm feq}}$ maximal?  As we have not
proved this even for ultrafilters, the reasonable hope is that it will
be easier to show non-maximality for $\triangleleft^{{\rm rp}}_\lambda$.  
Also in light of \cite{MiSh:1030} for simple theories we like to
prove non-maximality with no large cardinals.  We may hope to use just
${\rm NSOP}_2$, but still it would not settle the problem of characterizing
the maximal ones as, e.g. ${\rm SOP}_2 \equiv {\rm SOP}_3$ is open; for such
$T$; for a pair $(T,\varphi(\bar x,\bar y))$ they are different.

Note that for first order $T$, it makes sense to use $\mu^+$-saturated
models and $D$ is $\mu^+$-complete.

Also the ``$T$ stable" case should be resolved.

\begin{conjecture}
\label{b41}
$M^\lambda /D$ is ($\aleph^\lambda_0/D$,atomically)-saturated {\underline{when}} \,:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $T$ a theory as in \ref{x2}
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  $T$ is stable without the ${\rm fcp}$ 
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  $D$ is a $(\lambda,\aleph_0)$-regular filter on $\lambda$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{conjecture}

\begin{remark}

Maybe given a $1-\varphi$-type $p \subseteq \{\varphi(x,\bar a):
\bar a \in{}^m(M^I/D)\}$ of cardinality $\le \lambda$ in $M^I/D$, we
try just to find a dense set of $A \in D^+$ such that in $M^I/(D+A)$ the
$1-\varphi$-type is realized.  Then continue; opaque.
\end{remark}
\bigskip

\subsection {Preliminaries} \
\bigskip

\begin{notation}
\label{z1}
1) Let ${\mathfrak B}$ denote a Boolean algebra, ${\rm comp}({\mathfrak B})$ its completion, ${\mathfrak B}^+
= {\mathfrak B} \backslash \{0_B\},{\rm uf}({\mathfrak B})$ the set of ultrafilters on ${\mathfrak B},
{\rm fil}({\mathfrak B})$ the set of filters on ${\mathfrak B}$.  For $\bold a \in \bold B$ let
$\bold a^{{\rm if}({\rm true})} = \bold a^{{\rm if}(1)}$ be $\bold a$ and let
$\bold a^{{\rm if}({\rm false})} = \bold a^{{\rm if}(0)}$ be $1_{{\mathfrak B}} - \bold a$.

\noindent
2) For a model $M$ let $\tau_M = \tau(M)$ be its vocabulary.
\end{notation}

\noindent
Now about cuts (they are different than gaps, see
\cite{MiSh:1069}).

\begin{definition}
\label{z2}
1) For a partial order ${\mathscr T} = ({\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}})$, we say $(C_1,C_2)$ is
pre-cut {\underline{when}} \,:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $C_1 \cup C_2$ is a subset of ${\mathscr T}$ linearly ordered by
  $\le_{{\mathscr T}}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  if $a_1 \in C_1,a_2 \in C_2$ then $a_1 \le_{{\mathscr T}} a_2$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  for no $c \in {\mathscr T}$ do we have $a_1 \in C_1 \rightarrow
a_1 \le_{{\mathscr T}} c$ and $a_2 \in C_2 \Rightarrow c \le_{{\mathscr T}} a_2$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
2) Above we say $(C_1,C_2)$ is a $(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$-pre-cut {\underline{when}} \, in
addition:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(d)$]  $C_1$ has cofinality $\kappa_1$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(e)$]  $C^*_2$, the inverse of $C_2$, has cofinality $\kappa_2$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(f)$]  so $\kappa_1,\kappa_2$ are regular or 0 or 1.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
3) We may replace $C_\ell$ by a sequence $\bar a_\ell$, if not said
otherwise such that $\bar a_1$ is $\le_{{\mathscr T}}$-increasing and $\bar a_2$ is 
$\le_{{\mathscr T}}$-decreasing.

\noindent
4) We say $(C_1,C_2)$ is a $(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$-linear-cut of ${\mathscr T}$ {\underline{when}}
\, it is a $(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$-pre-cut and $C_1 \cup C_2$ is
downward closed, so natural for ${\mathscr T}$ a tree.

\noindent
5) We say $(C_1,C_2)$ is a weak cut {\underline{when}} \, (b),(c) of part (1) holds.

\noindent
6) We may write cut instead of pre-cut.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
\label{z3}
If ${\mathscr T}$ is a (model theoretic) tree, $\kappa_2 > 0$ and $(C_1,C_2)$
is a $(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$-pre-cut {\underline{then}} \, it induces one and only
one $(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$-linear-cut 
$(C'_1,C'_2)$, i.e. one satisfying $C_1 \subseteq
C'_1,C_2 \subseteq C'_2$ such that $C_1 \cup C_2$ is cofinal in $C'_1
\cup C'_2$.
\end{remark}

\begin{definition}
\label{z6}
1) We say $M$ is fully $(\lambda,\theta,\sigma,L)$-saturated 
(may omit the fully); where $L \subseteq 
{\mathscr L}(\tau_M)$ and ${\mathscr L}$ is a logic; we may write 
${\mathscr L}$ if $L = {\mathscr L}(\tau_M)$, {\underline{when}} \,: 
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  if $\Gamma$ is a set of $< \lambda$ formulas from $L$ 
with parameters from $M$ with $< 1 + \sigma$ free variables, and
$\Gamma$ is $(< \theta)$-satisfiable in $M$, {\underline{then}} \,
$\Gamma$ is realized in $M$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
2) We say ``locally" when using one $\varphi = \varphi(\bar x,\bar y) \in
{\mathscr L}$ with $\ell g(\bar x) < 1 + \sigma$, i.e. all members of 
$\Gamma$ have the form\footnote{In \cite{Sh:1019} we use a $L
  \subseteq {\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta},\theta$ a compact cardinal and if
  $\sigma > \theta$ we use a slightly different version of the
  definition of local and of the default values of $\sigma$ was
  $\theta$.}  $\varphi(\bar x,\bar b)$.

\noindent
3) Saying ``locally/fully $(\lambda,{\mathscr L})$-saturated" the default
values (i.e. we may omit) of $\sigma$ is $\sigma = \theta$, 
of $(\sigma,\theta)$ is $\theta = \aleph_0 \wedge \sigma
= \aleph_0$ and of ${\mathscr L}$ is ${\mathbb L}$ (first order logic) and of $L$ is ${\mathscr L}$.
Omitting ${\mathscr L}$ means ${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}$, omitting $\lambda$ means 
$\lambda = \|M\|$.

\noindent
4) If $\varphi(\bar x,y) \in{\mathscr L}(\tau_M)$ and $\bar a \in {}^{\ell
  g(\bar y)}M$ then $\varphi(M,\bar a) := \{\bar b \in {}^{\ell g(\bar
  x)}M:M \models \varphi [\bar b,\bar a]\}$.

\noindent
5) Let $\bar x_{[u]} = \langle x_s:s \in u\rangle$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
\label{z9}
Assume we are given 
a Boolean Algebra ${\mathfrak B}$ usually complete and a model or a set $M$
and $D$ a filter on ${\rm comp}({\mathfrak B})$, the completion of ${\mathfrak B}$.

\noindent
1) Let $M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ be the set of partial functions $f$ from
 ${\mathfrak B}^+ := {\mathfrak B} \backslash \{0_{{\mathfrak B}}\}$ into $M$ such that 
for some maximal antichain $\langle
   a_i:i < i(*)\rangle$ of ${\mathfrak B},{\rm Dom}(f)$ includes $\{a_i:i < i(*)\}$
 and is included in\footnote{for the $D_\ell \in {\rm uf}({\mathfrak B}_\ell)$ 
ultra-product, {\rm without loss of generality} \, ${\mathfrak B}$ is complete, then
{\rm without loss of generality} \, $f {\restriction} \{a_i:i < i(*)\}$ is one to one.  But in general we
allow $a_i = 0_{{\mathfrak B}}$, those are redundant but natural in
\ref{z9}(3).} $\{a \in {\mathfrak B}^+
:(\exists i)(a \le a_i)\}$ and $f$ is a function into $M$ and $f {\restriction} \{a \in
  {\rm Dom}(f):a \le a_i\}$ is constant for each $i$.

\noindent
1A) Naturally for $f_1,f_2 \in M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ we say $f_1,f_2$ are
$D$-equivalent, or $f_1 = f_2 \mod D$ {\underline{when}} \, for some $b \in D$ we have
$a_1 \in {\rm Dom}(f_1) \wedge a_2 \in {\rm Dom}(f_2) \wedge a_1 \cap a_2 \cap b
 > 0_{{\mathfrak B}} \Rightarrow f_1(a_1) = f_2(a_2)$.

\noindent
2) We define $M^{{\mathfrak B}}/D$ naturally,
as well as ${\rm TV}(\varphi(f_0,\dotsc,f_{n-1})) \in {\rm comp}({\mathfrak B})$ {\underline{when}} \,
$\varphi(x_0,\dotsc,x_{n-1}) \in {\mathbb L}(\tau_M)$ and $f_0,\dotsc,f_{n-1} \in
 M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ where ${\rm TV}$ stands for truth value and $M^{{\mathfrak B}}/D \models
\varphi[f_0/D,\dotsc,f_{n-1}/D]$ iff 
${\rm TV}_M(\varphi(f_0,\dotsc,f_{n-1})) \in D$. 

\noindent
2A) Abusing notation, not only $M^{{\mathfrak B}_1} \subseteq M^{{\mathfrak B}_2}$ but
$M^{{\mathfrak B}_1}/D_1 \subseteq M^{{\mathfrak B}_2}/D_2$ when ${\mathfrak B}_1 \lessdot
{\mathfrak B}_2,D_\ell \in {\rm fil}({\mathfrak B}_\ell)$ for $\ell=1,2$ and $D_1 = {\mathfrak B}_1 \cap
D_2$.  Also $[f_1,f_2 \in M^{{\mathfrak B}_1} \Rightarrow f_1 = f_2 \mod D_1
\leftrightarrow f_1 = f_2 \mod D_2]$.  So for 
$f \in M^{{\mathfrak B}_1}$ we identify $f/D_1$ and $f/D_2$.

\noindent
3) For complete ${\mathfrak B}$, we say $\langle a_n:n < \omega\rangle$ represents $f \in
{\mathbb N}^{{\mathbb B}}$ {\underline{when}} \, $\langle a_n:n < \omega\rangle$ is a maximal
antichain of ${\mathfrak B}$ (so $a_n = 0_{{\mathfrak B}}$ is allowed) 
and for some $f' \in {\mathbb N}^{{\mathfrak B}}$ which is 
$D$-equivalent to $f$ (see \ref{z9}(1A)) we have $f'(a_n)=n$.

\noindent
4) We say $\langle (a_n,k_n):n < \omega\rangle$ represent $f \in
{\mathbb N}^{{\mathfrak B}}$ {\underline{when}} \,:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  the $k_n$ are natural numbers with no repetition
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  $\langle a_n:n < \omega \rangle$ is a maximal antichain
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  $f(a_n) = k_n$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
5) If ${\mathscr I}$ is a maximal antichain of ${\mathfrak B}$ and $\bar M = \langle
M_a:a \in {\mathscr I}\rangle$ is a sequence of $\tau$-models, then we define
$\bar M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ be the set of partial functions $f$ from ${\mathfrak B}^+$ to
$\cup\{M_a:a \in {\mathscr I}\}$ such that for some maximal antichain $\langle
a_i:i < i(*)\rangle$ of ${\mathfrak B}$ refining ${\mathscr I}$ (i.e. $(\forall i <
i(*))(\exists b \in {\mathscr I})(a_i \le_{{\mathfrak B}} b))$ we have:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $(\{a_i:i <i(*)\} \subseteq {\rm dom}(f) \subseteq \{b \in
  {\mathfrak B}^+:b \le_{{\mathfrak B}} a_i$ for some $i <i(*)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  if $a \in {\rm dom}(f)$ and $a \le a_i$ then $f(a) = f(a_i)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  if $a_i \le_{{\mathfrak B}} b,b \in {\mathscr I}$ then $f(a_i) \in M_b$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
6) For $\bar M,{\mathfrak B},{\mathscr I}$ as above and a filter $D$ on ${\mathfrak B}$ we define
$\bar M^{{\mathfrak B}}/D$ as in part (2) replacing $M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ there by $\bar
M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ here.

\noindent
7) For $\bar M,{\mathfrak B},{\mathscr I}$ as above, $\varphi = \varphi(\bar x) =
\varphi(x_0,\dotsc,x_{n-1}) \in {\mathbb L}(\tau_M)$ and $\bar f = \langle
f_\ell:\ell < n\rangle$ where $f_0,\dotsc,f_{n-1} \in \bar M^{{\mathfrak B}}$,
let ${\rm TV}(\varphi[\bar f]) = {\rm TV}(\varphi[\bar f],\bar M^{{\mathfrak B}})$ be
$\sup\{a \in {\mathfrak B}^+$: if $\ell < n$ then $a \in {\rm dom}(f_\ell)$ and $a
\le b \in {\mathscr I}$ then $M_b \models \varphi[f_0(b),\dotsc,f_{n-1}(b)]$.

\noindent
8) We say ${\mathfrak B}$ is $\theta$-distributive {\underline{when}} \,: if $\alpha <
\theta,{\mathscr I}_i$ is a maximal antichain of ${\mathfrak B}$ for $\alpha < \alpha_*$
{\underline{then}} \, there is a maximal antichain of ${\mathfrak B}$ refining every
${\mathscr I}_\alpha(\alpha < \alpha_*)$; this holds, e.g. when 
${\mathfrak B} = {\mathscr P}(\lambda)$ or just
there is a dense $Y \subseteq {\mathfrak B}^+$ closed under intersection of $<
\theta$.  In this case, if $\alpha_* < \theta,\bar M,{\mathfrak B},{\mathscr I}$ as in
part (7), $\varepsilon < \theta,\varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]}) \in
{\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}$ or any logic $f_\zeta \in \bar M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ for
$\zeta < \varepsilon$ the ${\rm TV}(\varphi[\bar f])$ is defined as in part (7).
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
\label{z10}
Let ${\mathfrak B}$ be a complete Boolean algebra and $D$ a filter on ${\mathfrak B}$.  We
say that $D$ is $(\mu,\theta)$-regular {\underline{when}} \, for some 
$(\bar{\bold c},{\mathscr I})$ we have:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $\bar{\bold c} = \langle \bold c_\alpha:\alpha <
  \alpha_*\rangle$ is a maximal antichain
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  $\bar u = \langle u_\alpha:\alpha < \alpha_*\rangle$
  with $u_\alpha \in [\mu]^{< \theta}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  if $i < \mu$ then $\sup\{\bold c_\alpha:\alpha$ satisfies $i
  \in u_\alpha\} \in D$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{claim}
\label{z12}
Assume ${\mathfrak B}$ is a complete Boolean which is $\theta$-distributive and
$D$ a fitler on ${\mathfrak B}$ and $\theta = {\rm cf}(\theta)$.

\noindent
1) The parallel of \L os theorem holds for
${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}$ and if $D$ is $\lambda$-complete even for
${\mathbb L}_{\lambda,\theta}$ which means: if $\bar M = \langle M_b:b \in
{\mathscr I}\rangle$ is a sequence of $\tau$-models, ${\mathscr I}$ is a maximal
antichain of the complete Boolean Algebra ${\mathfrak B}$ and $\varepsilon <
\theta,\varphi = \varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]}) \in
{\mathbb L}_{\lambda,\theta}(\tau)$ and $f_\zeta \in \bar M^{{\mathfrak B}}$ for $\zeta
< \varepsilon$ then $M \models ``\varphi[\langle f_\zeta/D:\zeta <
\varepsilon\rangle]"$ iff ${\rm TV}(\varphi[\langle f_\zeta/D:\zeta <
\varepsilon\rangle]$ belongs to $D$.

\noindent
2) If $D$ is $\lambda$-regular and $M,N$ are
${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}$-equivalent then $M^{{\mathfrak B}}/D,N^{{\mathfrak B}}/D$ are
${\mathbb L}_{\lambda^+,\theta}$-equivalent. 
\end{claim}

\begin{definition}
\label{z16}
1) Assume $\Delta_\ell$ is a of set atomic formulas in ${\mathbb L}(\tau(T_\ell))$.
Then we say $(T_1,\Delta_1) \trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_{\lambda,\theta} 
(T_2,\Delta_2)$ {\underline{when}} \,: if $D$ is
  a $\lambda$-regular filter on $\lambda$ and $M_\ell$ is a
  ($\lambda^+$-saturated) model of $T_\ell$ for $\ell=1,2$ and
  $M^\lambda_2/D$ is $(\lambda,\theta,\Delta_2)$-saturated {\underline{then}} \,
  $M^\lambda_1/D$ is $(\lambda,\theta,\Delta_1)$-saturated.

\noindent
2) For general $\Delta_1,\Delta_2$ we define $(T_1,\Delta_1)
\trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_{\lambda,\theta} (T_2,\Delta_2)$ as meaning
$(T^+_1,\Delta^+_1) \trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_{\lambda,\theta}
(T^+_2,\Delta^+_2)$ where (as Morley \cite{Mo65} does):
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $T^+_\ell = T_\ell \cup \{(\forall \bar
  x)(\varphi(\bar x) \equiv P_\varphi(\bar x)):\varphi(\bar x) \in
  \Delta_\ell\}$ with $\langle P^\ell_\varphi:\varphi \in
  \Delta_\ell\rangle$ new pairwise distinct predicates with suitable
  number of places
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $\Delta^+_\ell = \{P^\ell_\varphi(\bar x_\varphi):
\varphi \in \Delta_\ell\}$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
3) In (2), $T_1 \trianglelefteq^{{\rm rp}}_{\lambda,\theta} T_2$ means
$\Delta_\ell =$ the set of atomic
${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_{T_\ell})$-formulas. 
\end{definition}
\newpage

\section {Axiomatizing \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:c}} \label{1}

\begin{definition}  
\label{h2}
1) For partial order ${\mathscr T} = ({\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}})$ 
let ${\mathfrak p}_{{\mathscr T}} = {\mathfrak p}({\mathscr T})$ be $\min\{\kappa_1 +
\kappa_2:(\kappa_1,\kappa_2) \in {\mathscr C}_{{\mathscr T}}\}$ and ${\mathfrak p}_\theta({\mathscr T}) =
\min\{\kappa_1 + \kappa_2:(\kappa_1,\kappa_2) \in {\mathscr C}_{{\mathscr T},\theta}\}$;
where:

\noindent
2) ${\mathscr C}_{{\mathscr T}} = {\mathscr C}({\mathscr T}) = C_{{\mathscr T},\theta}$ where ${\mathscr C}_{{\mathscr T},\theta} =
\{(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$: the partial order ${\mathscr T},
\kappa \ge \aleph_0$ has a $(\kappa_1,\kappa_2)$-cut
 and $\kappa_1 \ge \theta,\kappa_2 \ge \aleph_0\}$.

\noindent
3) For a partial order ${\mathscr T}$ let ${\mathfrak t}_{{\mathscr T}} = {\mathfrak t}({\mathscr T})$ be the minimal $\kappa
  \ge \aleph_0$ such that there is a $<_{{\mathscr T}}$-increasing sequence 
of length $\kappa$ with no $<_{{\mathscr T}}$-upper bound.

\noindent
4) Let ${\mathfrak p}^*_{{\mathscr T}} = {\mathfrak p}^*({\mathscr T})$ be $\min\{{\mathfrak t}_{{\mathscr T}},{\mathfrak p}_{{\mathscr T}}\}$.

\noindent
5) ${\mathfrak p}^*_{{\rm sym}}({\mathscr T}) = \min\{\kappa:(\kappa,\kappa) \in {\mathscr C}({\mathscr T})\}$.

\noindent
6) In Definition \ref{h4} below let ${\mathfrak t}_{\bold r} = {\mathfrak t}_{{\mathscr T}_{\bold r}},
{\mathfrak p}_{\bold r} = {\mathfrak p}_{{\mathscr T}_{\bold r},\theta_{\bold r}}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}  
\label{h4}
1) For $\iota = 1,2$ we say $\bold r$ or $(M,\Delta)$ is a
$(\theta,\iota)$-realization\footnote{When $P$ and $\tau_N$ (hence
  $N$) are
understood from the context we may omit them} spectrum problem, in short
$(\theta,\iota)-{\rm RSP}$ or $(\theta,\iota)-1$-RSP {\underline{when}} \, $\bold r$ 
consists of (if $\iota =2$ we may omit it, similarly if $\theta =
\aleph_0$; we may omit $\Delta$ and write $M$ when $\Delta$ is the set of
atomic formulas in ${\mathbb L}(\tau_{N_M})$, see below, so $M$ below $=
M_{\bold r}$, etc.):
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $M$ a model
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  for the relations ${\mathscr T} = {\mathscr T}^M,\le_{{\mathscr T}} = \le^M_{{\mathscr T}}$ of $M$
  (i.e. ${\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}}$ are predicates from $\tau_M$) we have
${\mathscr T} = ({\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}})$ a partial order (so definable in $M$) with
  root $c^M = {\rm rt}({\mathscr T})$, so $c \in \tau_M$ is an individual constant
  and $t \in {\mathscr T} \Rightarrow {\rm rt}({\mathscr T}) \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$; as in other cases
we may write ${\mathscr T}_{\bold r},\le_{\bold r}$ for ${\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}}$; we do
not require ${\mathscr T}$ to be a tree; but do require $t \in {\mathscr T}
\Rightarrow t \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  a model $N = N_{\bold r} = N_M$ 
with universe $P^M,\tau(N) \subseteq \tau(M)$ such that
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $Q \in \tau_N \Rightarrow Q^M = Q^N$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $F \in \tau_N \Rightarrow F^N = F^M$, (we
  understand $F^M,F^N$ to be partial functions), 
\newline
so every $\varphi \in {\mathbb L}(\tau_N)$ can be
interpreted as $\varphi^{[*]} \in {\mathbb L}(\tau_M)$, all variables varying
on $P$ (include quantification); we may forget the $[*]$.
\end{enumerate}
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(d)$]  the cardinal $\theta$ and 
$\Delta \subseteq \{\varphi:\varphi = \varphi(x,\bar y)
  \in {\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_N)\}$ which is closed under
  conjunctions meaning: if $\varphi_\ell(x,\bar y_\ell) \in 
\Delta$ for $\ell=1,2$ then
 $\varphi(x,\bar y'_1,\bar y''_2) = \varphi_1(x,\bar y'_1)
\wedge \varphi_2(\bar x,\bar y''_2) \in \Delta$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(e)$]  $R^M \subseteq |N| \times {\mathscr T}^M$ so a two-place relation;
and let $R^M_t = \{b:b R^M t\}$ for $t \in {\mathscr T}^M$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(f)$]  $|N| \times \{{\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}}\} \subseteq R^M$,
  i.e. $R^M_{{\rm rt}({\mathscr T})} = |N|$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(g)$]  if $s \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$ then $a \in N \wedge aRt \Rightarrow
  aRs$, i.e. $R^M_s \supseteq R^M_t$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(h)$]  $t \in {\mathscr T} \Rightarrow R^M_t \ne \emptyset$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(i)$]  if $s \in {\mathscr T},\varphi(x,\bar a) \in \Delta(N) :=
  \{\varphi(x,\bar a)):\varphi(x,\bar y) \in \Delta$ and $\bar a \in {}^{\ell
  g(\bar y)}N\}$ and for some $b \in R^M_s,N \models \varphi[b,\bar
  a]$ {\underline{then}} \, there is $t \in {\mathscr T}$ such that $s \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$ and
$R^M_t = \{b \in R^M_s:N \models \varphi[b,\bar a]\}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(i)^+$]  if $\iota=1$ like clause $(i)$ 
but\footnote{We may not add a function, maybe it matters 
when we try to build $\bold r$ with ${\rm Th}(M_{\bold
  r})$-nice first order} moreover $t = F^M_{\varphi,1}(s,\bar a)$
where $F^M_{\varphi,1}:{\mathscr T}_{\bold r} \times {}^{\ell g(\bar y)}(P^M)
  \rightarrow {\mathscr T}_{\bold r}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(j)$]  if $t \in {\mathscr T}_{\bold r}$ and $\varphi(x,\bar a) \in
  \Delta(N)$ and $\varphi(N,\bar a) \ne \emptyset$ {\underline{then}}
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(\alpha)$]  $s = F^M_{\varphi,2}(t,\bar a)$ is such that $R^M_s
  \cap \varphi(N,\bar a) \ne \emptyset$ and $s \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\beta)$]  if $s = F^M_{\varphi,2}(t,\bar a),s_1 \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$
  and $R^M_{s_1} \cap \varphi(N,\bar a) \ne \emptyset$ then $s_1
  \le_{{\mathscr T}} s$
\end{enumerate}
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(k)$]  if $\theta > \aleph_0$ then in
$({\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}})$ any increasing chain of length $< \theta$
which has an upper bound has a $\le_{{\mathscr T}}$-lub.
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
\label{h5}
We may consider adding: $S^M$ a being successor, (but this is not
Horn), i.e.:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(l)$] if $\iota =1$ we also have $S^M = \{(a,b):B$ is a
  $\le_{{\mathscr T}}$-successor of $a$ such that
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(\alpha)$]  if $a \le b \wedge a \ne b$ then for some
  $c,S(a,c) \wedge c \le b$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\beta)$]  if $b \in {\mathscr T} \backslash \{{\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}}\}$ then for
  some unique $a$ we have $S^M(a,b)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\gamma)$]  $S(a,b) \Rightarrow a \le b$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\delta)$]  $S(a,b_1) \wedge S(a,b_2) \wedge b_1 \ne b_2
  \Rightarrow \neg(b_1 \le b_2)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\varepsilon)$]  in clause (j) we can add $S^M(s,t)$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\end{remark}

\begin{remark}  
\label{h5d}
Presently, it may be that $a \le_{{\mathscr T}} b \le_{{\mathscr T}} a$ but $a \ne b$.  Not a
disaster to forbid but no reason.
\end{remark}

\noindent
How does this axiomatize realizations of types?
\begin{cd}  
\label{h6}
Let $\iota = \{1,2\},\theta$ is $\aleph_0$ or just a regular cardinal.

\noindent
1) For any model $N$ and $\Delta \subseteq \{\varphi =
   \varphi(x,\bar y) \in {\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_T)\}$ closed under
   conjunctions of $< \theta$, the canonical $(\theta,\iota)-{\rm RSP},
   \bold r = \bold r^\theta_{N,\Delta}$ defined below is indeed a 
$\theta-{\rm RSP}$.

\noindent
2) $\bold r = \bold r^\theta_{N,\Delta}$ (if $\theta = \aleph_0$ we may
omit it) is defined by:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$] $\Delta_{\bold r} = \Delta,N_{\bold r} = N$ and
  $\theta_{\bold r} = \theta$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  ${\mathscr T}_{\bold r} = \{\langle \varphi_\varepsilon(x,
\bar a_\varepsilon):\varepsilon < \zeta\rangle:\zeta < \theta$ 
and for every $\varepsilon < \zeta$ we have 
$\varphi_\varepsilon(x,\bar a_\varepsilon) \in \Delta(N)$ 
and $N \models (\exists x)(\bigwedge\limits_{\varepsilon <
  \zeta} \varphi_\varepsilon(x,\bar a_\varepsilon))\}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(c)$]  $\le_{\bold r} =$ being the initial segment relation
  on ${\mathscr T}_{\bold r}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(d)$]  $M = M_{\bold r}$ is the model with universe 
${\mathscr T}_{\bold r} \cup |N|$; {\rm without loss of generality} \, ${\mathscr T}_{\bold r} \cap |N| =
\emptyset$, with the relations and functions of $N,{\mathscr T}_r,\le_{\bold r}$ and
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $P^M = |N|$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $c^M = \langle \rangle \in {\mathscr T}_{\bold r}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $R^M = \{(b,t):a \in N,t = \langle
  \varphi_{t,\varepsilon}(x,\bar a_{t,\varepsilon}):\varepsilon 
< \zeta_t\rangle \in {\mathscr T}$ and $N \models \varphi_{t,\ell}
(b,\bar a_{t,\varepsilon})$ for every $\varepsilon < \zeta_t\}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $F^M_{\varphi,2}$ as in Definition \ref{h4}(j)
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  if $\iota=1$ then $F^M_{\varphi,1}$ is as in
Definition \ref{h4}(i)$^+$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\end{cd}

\begin{remark}
\label{h7}
If we adopt \ref{h5} it is natural to add:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(e)$]  for $\iota = 1,S^M =
  \{(\bar\varphi_1,\bar\varphi_2):\bar\varphi_2 = \varphi_1 \char 94
  \langle \varphi(x,\bar a)\rangle \in {\mathscr T}_{\bold r}$ 
for some $\varphi(x,\bar a) \in \Delta(N)\}$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{remark}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{h6}}  
Obvious.
\end{PROOF}

\begin{mc}  
\label{h8}
1) Assume $\bold r$ is an ${\rm RSP}$.  If $\kappa = \min\{{\mathfrak t}_{\bold r},
{\mathfrak p}_{\bold r}\}$ {\underline{then}} \, the
model $N$ is $(\kappa,1,\Delta_{\bold r})$-saturated, i.e.
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\oplus$]  if $p(x) \subseteq \Delta_{\bold r}(N_{\bold r})$ is
  finitely satisfiable in $N_{\bold r}$ (= is a type in $N_{\bold r}$) of
  cardinality $< \kappa$ {\underline{then}}\, $p$ is realized in $N_{\bold r}$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
2) If $\theta > \aleph_0$ and $\bold r$ is a $\theta$-RSP, 
{\underline{then}} \, $N_{\bold r}$ is
$(\kappa,1,\Delta_{\bold r})$-saturated where $\kappa =
\min\{{\mathfrak t}_{\bold r},{\mathfrak p}_{\bold r}\}$ recalling \ref{h2}(6),
i.e. ${\mathfrak p}_{\bold r} = {\mathfrak p}_{{\mathscr T}_{\bold r},\theta}$.

\noindent
3) If $\theta > \aleph_0,\bold r$ is a $\theta$-RSP satisfying $(k)^+$
below {\underline{then}} \, $N_{\bold r}$ is $({\mathfrak t}_{\bold r},1,
\Delta_{\bold r})$-saturated {\underline{when}} \,:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(k)^+$]  in $({\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}})$ any increasing chain which has an
upper bound, has a $\le_{{\mathscr T}}$-lub.
\end{enumerate}
\end{mc}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{h8}}  
This is an abstract version of \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:a} = \cite[Ch.VI,2.6]{Sh:c};
recall that \cite[Ch.VI,2.7]{Sh:a} translates trees to linear orders.

\noindent
1) Let $N = N_{\bold r},\Delta = \Delta_{\bold r}$, etc.

Let $p$ be a $(\Delta,1)$-type in $N$ of cardinality $< \kappa$.
{\rm Without loss of generality} \, $p$ is infinite and closed under conjunctions.

So let
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(*)_1$]  $\alpha_* < \kappa,p = \{\varphi_\alpha(x,\bar
  a_\alpha):\alpha < \alpha_*\} \subseteq \Delta(N),p$ is finitely
  satisfiable in $N$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
We shall try to choose $t_\alpha$ by induction on $\alpha \le \alpha_*$
such that
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(*)_2$]  $(a) \quad t_\alpha \in {\mathscr T}$ and $\beta < \alpha
  \Rightarrow t_\beta \le_{{\mathscr T}} t_\alpha$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $(b) \quad$ if $\beta < \alpha_*$ then there
  is $b \in R^M_{t_\alpha}$ such that $N \models \varphi_\beta[b,\bar
  a_\beta]$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $(c) \quad$ if $\beta < \alpha$ then $b \in
  R^M_{t_\alpha} \Rightarrow N \models \varphi_\beta[b,\bar a_\alpha]$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
If we succeed, this is enough because if $t = 
t_{\alpha_*}$ is well defined then
$R^M_t \ne \emptyset$ by Definition \ref{h4}(h) and any 
$b \in R^M_t$ realizes the type by $(*)_2(c)$ and Definition
\ref{h4}(h).   Why can we carry the definition?
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Case 1}:  $\alpha = 0$

Let $t_\alpha = {\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}}$, hence $R^M_{t_\alpha} = |N|$ by Definition
\ref{h4}(f).  Now clause (a) of $(*)_2$ holds as $t_\alpha \in 
{\mathscr T}_{\bold r}$ and there is no $\beta <
\alpha$.  Also clause (b) of $(*)_2$ holds because $p$ is a type
and $R^M_{{\rm rt}({\mathscr T})} = |N_{\bold r}|$ by Definition \ref{h4}(h).

Lastly, clause (c) of $(*)_2$ holds trivially.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Case 2}: $\alpha = \beta +1$

If $\iota =1$ let $t = F^M_{\varphi_\beta,1}(t_\beta,\bar a_\beta)$ 
and see clause (i)$^+$ of Definition \ref{h4}.  If $\iota=2$ use
clause (i) of the definition recalling $p$ is closed under conjunctions.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Case 3}:  $\alpha$ a limit ordinal

As ${\mathfrak t}_{{\mathscr T}_{\bold r}} \ge \kappa > \alpha_*$ by the claim's 
assumption (on ${\mathfrak t}_{{\mathscr T}_{\bold r}}$, see Definition \ref{h2}(2)) 
necessarily there is $s \in {\mathscr T}$ such that
$\beta < \alpha \Rightarrow t_\alpha \le_{{\mathscr T}} s$.  We now try to choose
$s_i$ by induction on $i \le \alpha_*$ such that
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(*)_{2.1}$]  $(a) \quad s_i \in {\mathscr T}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $(b) \quad \beta < \alpha \Rightarrow t_\beta \le_{{\mathscr T}} s_i$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $(c) \quad j < i \Rightarrow s_i \le_{{\mathscr T}} s_j$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $(d) \quad$ if $i = j+1$ then $R^M_{s_i}$ is not
  disjoint to $\varphi_j(N,\bar a_j)$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
If we succeed, then $s_{\alpha_*}$ satisfies all the demands on
$t_\alpha$ (e.g. $(*)_2(b)$ holds by Definition \ref{h4}(g) and
$(*)_{2.1}(d))$,  so we have just to carry the induction for $\alpha$.  
Now if $i=0$ clearly $s_0 = s$ it as required.  If $i
=j+1$ let $s_i = F^M_{\varphi,2}(s_j,\bar a_j)$, by Definition
\ref{h4}(j) it is as required.  For $i$ a limit ordinal use 
$\kappa \le {\mathfrak p}_{{\mathscr T}}$ hence to carry the induction on $i$ so finish
case 3.  

So we succeed to carry the induction on $\alpha$ hence (as said after $(*)_2$) 
get the desired conclusion.

\noindent
2) Similar, except concerning case 3.  Note that {\rm without loss of generality} \, $\theta >
   \aleph_0$ by part (1).
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Case 3A}:  $\alpha$ is a limit ordinal of cofinality $\ge
\theta$

As in the proof of part (1).
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Case 3B}:  $\alpha$ is a limit ordinal of cofinality $< \theta$

Again there is an upper bound $s$ of $\{t_\beta:\beta < \alpha\}$.  Now
by clause (k) of Definition \ref{h4}, {\rm without loss of generality} \, $s$ is a $<_{{\mathscr T}}$-lub
of $\{t_\beta:\beta < \alpha\}$.  So easily for every $i <
\alpha_*,F^N_{\varphi_i,2}(s,\bar a_i)$ is $\ge t_\beta$ for $\beta <
\alpha$ hence is equal to $s$, so $s_\alpha := s$ is as required.

\noindent
3) Similarly.
\end{PROOF}

\begin{discussion}
\label{h10}
1) What about ``$(\lambda^+,n,\Delta)$-saturation"?  We can repeat the
same analysis or we can change the models to code $n$-tuples.  More
generally, replacing $\varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar y)$ 
by $\varphi(\langle F_\zeta(x):\zeta < \varepsilon\rangle,\bar y)$,
using $F_\zeta \in \tau_M$ (though not necessarily $F_\zeta \in
\tau_{N_{\bold r}}$), so we can allow infinite $\varepsilon$.

\noindent
2) Hence the same is true for
$(\lambda^+,\aleph_0,\Delta)$-saturation, e.g.
$\lambda^+$-saturated by an assumption.
\end{discussion}

\section {Applying the axiomatized frame} \label{2}

\noindent
Of course, (note that we do not require $D$ to be regular); if it is
$\lambda$-regular, then we can reduce $\mu$ if $D$ is
$\lambda$-regular, $\lambda \ge |\tau_N|$ then we can replace
$({}^{\omega >}\mu,\triangleleft)$ by $({}^{\omega
  >}\omega,\triangleleft)$, see \ref{z12}(2).

\begin{conclusion}
\label{c4}
1) If $D$ is an ultrafilter on a set $I,N$ a model, $\mu = \|N\| +
\|\tau_N\|$ and $({}^{\omega >}\mu,\triangleleft)^\lambda/D$ is
($\lambda^+$,atomically)-saturated {\underline{then}} \, $N^+/D$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated.

\noindent
2) Instead ``$({}^{\omega >}\mu,\trianglelefteq)^I/D$ is ($\lambda^+,1$,
atomically)-saturated" we can demand $J^I/D$ is
($\lambda^+,1$,atomic)-saturated where $J$ is the linear order with
set of elements $\{-1,1\} \times {}^{\omega >}\mu$ ordered by
$(\iota_1,\eta_1) < (\iota_2,\eta_2)$ {\underline{iff}} \, $\iota_1 < \iota_2$ or
$\iota_1 = -1 = \iota_2 \wedge \eta_1 <_{{\rm lex}} \eta_2$ or $\iota_1 =
-1 = \iota_2 \wedge \eta_2 <_{{\rm lex}} \eta_1$.
\end{conclusion}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{c4}}
1) Let $N_1 = N$.  
As $D$ is an ultrafilter {\rm without loss of generality} \, ${\rm Th}(N_1)$ has elimination of
quantifiers.  Let $\Delta = {\mathbb L}(\tau_N)$, by \ref{h6}  $\bold
r_1 := \bold r_{N_1,\Delta}$ is an RSP.  Let $N_2 = N^I_1/D = M_1 =
r_{\bold r_1},M_2 = M^I_1/D$ and let $\bold r_2$ be the 
${\rm RSP}(M_2,\Delta)$.  Clearly $\bold r_2$ is an RSP as the demands in 
\ref{h4} are first order (see more in \ref{c7}).  

Now
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(*)_1$]  ${\mathscr T}_{\bold r_1} \cong ({}^{\omega
    >}\mu,\triangleleft)$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
[Why?  See \ref{h6}(2).]
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(*)_2$]  ${\mathscr T}_{\bold r_2} = ({\mathscr T}_{r_1})^I/D$
is ($\lambda^+$,atomically)-saturated.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
[Why?  By an assumption.]
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(*)_3$]   ${\mathfrak t}({\mathscr T}_{\bold r_1}),{\mathfrak p}({\mathscr T}_{r_2}) \ge \lambda^+$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
[Why?  Follows by $(*)_2$.]

Hence by \ref{h8}, $N_2$ is $(\lambda^+,1,1,\Delta)$-saturated which
means $N_2 = (N_1)^I/D$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated.

\noindent
2) Easy (or see \cite[Ch.VI,2.7]{Sh:a} or see \cite{Sh:14}).
\end{PROOF}

To apply the criterion of the Main Claim \ref{h8} to reduced products
we need:
\begin{claim}
\label{c7}
If $\Delta$ is the set of conjunctions of atomic formulas (no
negation!) in ${\mathbb L}(\tau_0)$ and $\tau = \{{\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}},R,P,c\} \cup
\{F_{\varphi,\ell}:\varphi \in \Delta$ and $\ell=2$ or 
$\ell=1$ if relevant$\} \cup \tau_0$
(recall $c$ is ${\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}}$), {\underline{then}} \, there is set $T$ of Horn
sentences from ${\mathbb L}(\tau)$ such that for every $\tau$-model $M$
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $(M,\Delta)$ is a ${\rm RSP}$ (i.e. 2-RSP) {\underline{iff}} \, $M
  \models T$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{claim}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{c7}}
Consider Definition \ref{h4}.  For each clause we consider the
sentences expressing the clauses there.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (a)}:  Obvious
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (b)}:  Clearly the following are Horn:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $x \le_{{\mathscr T}} y \rightarrow {\mathscr T}(x),x \le_{{\mathscr T}} 
y \rightarrow {\mathscr T}(y)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $x \le_{{\mathscr T}} y \wedge y \le_{{\mathscr T}} z \rightarrow x
  \le_{{\mathscr T}} z$,
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  ${\mathscr T}({\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}})$ and ${\mathscr T}(s)
\rightarrow {\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}} \le s$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  ${\mathscr T}(x) \rightarrow x \le_{{\mathscr T}} x$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
Note that $({\mathscr T},\le_{{\mathscr T}})$ being a tree is not a Horn sentence but is
not required.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (c)}:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $Q(x_0,\dotsc,x_{n(Q)-1}) \rightarrow
P(x_\ell)$ when $Q$ is an $n(Q)$-place predicate from $\tau(N)$ and
$\ell < n(Q)$; clearly it is Horn
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  for any $n$-place function symbol $F \in \tau_0$ the sentence:
$P(x_0) \wedge \ldots \wedge P(x_{n-1}) \rightarrow
P(F(x_0,\dotsc,x_{n-1}))$ and $y = F(x_0,\dotsc,x_{n-1}) \rightarrow
P(x_\ell)$.  
\end{enumerate}
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (d)}:  nothing to prove - see the present claim
assumption on $\Delta$.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (e)}:  $yRs \rightarrow {\mathscr T}(s),yRs 
\rightarrow P(y)$ are Horn.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (f)}: $P(x) \rightarrow xR({\rm rt}_{{\mathscr T}})$ is Horn.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (g)}: $s \le_{{\mathscr T}} t \wedge xRt \rightarrow xRs$ is Horn.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (h)}:  $(\forall t)(\exists x)({\mathscr T}(t) \rightarrow
xRt)$ is Horn.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (i)}:  Let $\varphi(x,\bar y) \in \Delta$.  

First assume $\iota = 1$.  Note the following are Horn: for any
$\varphi(x,\bar y) \in \Delta$
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  ${\mathscr T}(s) \wedge xRs \wedge \varphi(x,\bar y) \wedge
 \bigwedge\limits_{\ell < \ell g(\bar y)} P(y_\ell) \wedge t =
 F_{\varphi,1}(s,\bar y) \rightarrow {\mathscr T}(t) \wedge s \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  ${\mathscr T}(s) \wedge xRs \wedge \varphi(x,\bar y) \wedge
  \bigwedge\limits_{\ell < \ell g(\bar y)} P(y_\ell) \wedge t
  = F_{\varphi,1}(s,\bar y) \rightarrow xRt$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  ${\mathscr T}(s) \wedge x'Rs \wedge 
x'RF_{\varphi,1}(s,\bar y) \rightarrow \varphi(x',\bar y)$.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
This suffices.  The proof when $\iota = 2$ is similar.
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (j)}:  Similarly but we give details. 

Let $\varphi = \varphi(x,\bar y) \in \Delta$, so the following are Horn:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$\bullet$]  $\varphi(x_1,\bar y) \wedge P(x_1)
  \wedge \bigwedge\limits_{\ell < \ell g(\bar y)} P(y_\ell) \wedge s = 
F_{\varphi,2}(t,\bar y) \rightarrow s \le_{{\mathscr T}} t$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $\varphi(x_1,\bar y) \wedge P(x_1)
  \wedge \bigwedge\limits_{\ell < \ell g(\bar y)} P(y_\ell) \wedge s = 
F_{\varphi,2}(t,\bar y) \rightarrow (\exists x)(xRs \wedge 
\varphi(x,\bar y))$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$\bullet$]  $P(x) \wedge \bigwedge\limits_{\ell < \ell g(\bar y)}
P(y_\ell) \wedge s = F_{\varphi,2}(t,\bar y) \wedge z \le_{{\mathscr T}} t \wedge xRz
  \wedge \varphi(x,\bar y) \rightarrow z \le_{{\mathscr T}} s$.
\end{enumerate}
\medskip

\noindent
\underline{Clause (k)}:  As $\theta = \aleph_0$ this is empty.

This suffices.
\end{PROOF}

\begin{claim}
\label{c10}
Also for $\theta > \aleph_0$ (see \ref{h4}(2)) Claim \ref{c7} 
holds but some of the formulas are in ${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}$.
\end{claim}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{c10}}
\underline{Clause $(k)$}:  When $\theta > \aleph_0$.  

Should be clear
because for each limit ordinal $\delta < \kappa$, the sentences
$\psi_\delta = (\forall x_0,\dotsc,x_\alpha,\dotsc,x_\delta)(\exists
y)(\forall z) \big( (\bigwedge\limits_{\alpha < \beta < \delta} x_\alpha

x_\beta \le_{{\mathscr T}} z \le_{{\mathscr T}} y \le_{{\mathscr T}} x_\delta 
\rightarrow y=z \large \big)$ is a Horn sentence
and it expresses ``any $\le_{{\mathscr T}}$-increasing chain of length $\delta$ has a
$\le$-lub". 
\end{PROOF}

1) No harm in assuming $\Delta = \{Q(\bar y):Q$ a predicate$\}$.  Note

\end{remark}

\section {Criterion for Atomic saturation of reduced powers} \label{3}\
\bigskip

\noindent
Malliaris-Shelah \cite{MiSh:998} dealt with such problem for
ultrafilters (on sets).  The main case here is $\theta = \aleph_0$.
\begin{definition}
\label{g3}
Assume $D$ is a filter on the complete Boolean Algebra ${\mathfrak B},T$ an
${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_T)$-theory, $\Delta \subseteq {\mathbb L}(\tau_T)$
and $\mu \ge |\Delta|$.  We say
$D$ is a $(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon!,\Delta,T)$-moral filter on ${\mathfrak B}$
(writing $\varepsilon$ instead $\varepsilon$! 
means for every $\varepsilon' < 1 +\varepsilon$;
if ${\mathfrak B} = {\mathscr P}(\lambda)$ we may say good instead of moral): {\underline{when}} \, for every
$D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon!,\Delta,T)$-problem there is a
$D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon,\Delta,T)$-solution \underline{where}:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $\bar{\bold a}$ is a 
$D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon !,\Delta,T)$-(moral)-problem {\underline{when}} \,:
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(\alpha)$]  $\bar{\bold a} = \langle \bold a_u:u \in [\mu]^{<
  \theta}\rangle$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\beta)$]  $\bold a_u \in D$ (hence $\in {\mathfrak B}^+$)
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\gamma)$]  $\bar{\bold a}$ is $\subseteq$-decreasing, that is
  $u \subseteq v \in [\mu]^{< \theta} \Rightarrow \bold a_v \le \bold
  a_u$ and $\bold a_\emptyset = 1_{{\mathfrak B}}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\delta)$]  for some sequence $\langle 
\varphi_\alpha(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar y_\alpha):\alpha 
< \mu\rangle$ of formulas
from $\Delta$ for every $\bold a \in {\mathfrak B} \backslash \{0\}$ and  
$u \subseteq \mu$ of cardinality $< \theta$ we can find $M
  \models T$ and $\bar b_\alpha \in {}^{\ell g(\bar y_\alpha)}M$ 
for $\alpha \in u$ such that: 
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $\bullet \quad$ for every $v \subseteq u$ we have
$\bold a \le \bold a_v \Rightarrow M \models 
``(\exists \bar x_{[\varepsilon]}) \, 
\bigwedge\limits_{\alpha \in v} \varphi_\alpha(\bar
x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar b_\alpha)"$

\hskip35pt  and $\bold a \le 1 - \bold a_v 
\Rightarrow M \models ``\neg(\exists \bar x_{[\varepsilon]})
  \bigwedge\limits_{\alpha \in v} \varphi_\alpha(\bar
  x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar b_\alpha)"$
\end{enumerate}
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  $\bar{\bold b}$ is a $D-(\mu,\theta)$-(moral)-solution 
of the $D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon,\Delta,T)$-(moral)-problem 
$\bar{\bold a}$ {\underline{when}} \,
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(\alpha)$]  $\bar{\bold b} = \langle \bold b_u:u \in 
[\mu]^{< \theta}\rangle$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\beta)$]  $\bold b_u \in D$ and $\bold b_\emptyset = 1_{{\mathfrak B}}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\gamma)$]  $\bold b_u \le \bold a_u$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\delta)$]  $\bar{\bold b}$ is multiplicative,
  i.e. $\bar{\bold b}_u = \cap\{\bold b_{\{\alpha\}}:\alpha \in u\}$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
\label{g5}
1) The $\theta$ here means ``a type is $(< \theta)$-satisfiable".

\noindent
2) The use of ``$\varepsilon!$" is to 
conform with Definition \ref{z6}.
\end{remark}

\noindent
Recall (from \ref{z6})
\begin{definition}
\label{g8}
Let $\tau$ be a vocabulary and $\Delta \subseteq \{\varphi \in
{\mathbb L}(\tau):\varphi = \varphi(\bar x,\bar y)\}$ but $\varphi(\bar x,\bar y) \in \Delta$ means we can add to
$\bar x$ dummy variables.  Let $\lambda > \theta$ (dull otherwise).

A $\tau$-model $M$ is $\langle \lambda,\theta,\varepsilon !,
\Delta \rangle$-saturated
{\underline{when}} \,: if $p \subseteq \{\varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar
a):\varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar y) \in \Delta,\bar a \in {}^{\ell
  g(\bar y)}M\}$ has cardinality $< \lambda$ 
is $(< \theta)$ satisfiable in $M$ {\underline{then}} \, $p$ is realized in $M$. 
\end{definition}

\label{g9}
1) For a $(\mu,\theta)$-regular $\theta$-complete ultra-filter 
$D$ on a set $I$ and $\theta$-saturated or just
$(\theta,\aleph_0,\varepsilon !,\Delta)$-saturated model $M$, a
cardinality $\mu$ and $\Delta =
{\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_M)$, the following conditions
are equivalent:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $D$ is $(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon !,\Delta,T)$-moral ultrafilter on the
  Boolean Algebra ${\mathscr P}(T)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  if $M \in {\rm Mod}_T$ then $M^I/D$ is 
$(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon !,\Delta,T)$-saturated.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
2) Similarly for $D$ a filter on a $\theta$-distributive (see \ref{z9}(8))
complete Boolean Algebra ${\mathfrak B}$.
\end{claim}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{g9}}
Similar to \ref{g10} it actually follows from it because as $D$ is an
ultra-filter, we can start with $M \models T$, expand it to $M^+$ by
adding a predicate to any definable relation and apply \ref{g10} to
$T^+ = {\rm Th}(M^+)$.

\section {Criterion for Atomic saturation of reduced powers} \label{3}\
\bigskip

\noindent
Malliaris-Shelah \cite{MiSh:998} dealt with such problem for
ultrafilters (on sets).  The main case here is $\theta = \aleph_0$.
\begin{definition}
\label{g3}
Assume $D$ is a filter on the complete Boolean Algebra ${\mathfrak B},T$ an
${\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_T)$-theory, $\Delta \subseteq {\mathbb L}(\tau_T)$
and $\mu \ge |\Delta|$.  We say
$D$ is a $(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon!,\Delta,T)$-moral filter on ${\mathfrak B}$
(writing $\varepsilon$ instead $\varepsilon$! 
means for every $\varepsilon' < 1 +\varepsilon$;
if ${\mathfrak B} = {\mathscr P}(\lambda)$ we may say good instead of moral): {\underline{when}} \, for every
$D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon!,\Delta,T)$-problem there is a
$D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon,\Delta,T)$-solution \underline{where}:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $\bar{\bold a}$ is a 
$D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon !,\Delta,T)$-(moral)-problem {\underline{when}} \,:
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(\alpha)$]  $\bar{\bold a} = \langle \bold a_u:u \in [\mu]^{<
  \theta}\rangle$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\beta)$]  $\bold a_u \in D$ (hence $\in {\mathfrak B}^+$)
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\gamma)$]  $\bar{\bold a}$ is $\subseteq$-decreasing, that is
  $u \subseteq v \in [\mu]^{< \theta} \Rightarrow \bold a_v \le \bold
  a_u$ and $\bold a_\emptyset = 1_{{\mathfrak B}}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\delta)$]  for some sequence $\langle 
\varphi_\alpha(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar y_\alpha):\alpha 
< \mu\rangle$ of formulas
from $\Delta$ for every $\bold a \in {\mathfrak B} \backslash \{0\}$ and  
$u \subseteq \mu$ of cardinality $< \theta$ we can find $M
  \models T$ and $\bar b_\alpha \in {}^{\ell g(\bar y_\alpha)}M$ 
for $\alpha \in u$ such that: 
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[${{}}$]  $\bullet \quad$ for every $v \subseteq u$ we have
$\bold a \le \bold a_v \Rightarrow M \models 
``(\exists \bar x_{[\varepsilon]}) \, 
\bigwedge\limits_{\alpha \in v} \varphi_\alpha(\bar
x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar b_\alpha)"$

\hskip35pt  and $\bold a \le 1 - \bold a_v 
\Rightarrow M \models ``\neg(\exists \bar x_{[\varepsilon]})
  \bigwedge\limits_{\alpha \in v} \varphi_\alpha(\bar
  x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar b_\alpha)"$
\end{enumerate}
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  $\bar{\bold b}$ is a $D-(\mu,\theta)$-(moral)-solution 
of the $D-(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon,\Delta,T)$-(moral)-problem 
$\bar{\bold a}$ {\underline{when}} \,
{\smallskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(\alpha)$]  $\bar{\bold b} = \langle \bold b_u:u \in 
[\mu]^{< \theta}\rangle$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\beta)$]  $\bold b_u \in D$ and $\bold b_\emptyset = 1_{{\mathfrak B}}$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\gamma)$]  $\bold b_u \le \bold a_u$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(\delta)$]  $\bar{\bold b}$ is multiplicative,
  i.e. $\bar{\bold b}_u = \cap\{\bold b_{\{\alpha\}}:\alpha \in u\}$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
\label{g5}
1) The $\theta$ here means ``a type is $(< \theta)$-satisfiable".

\noindent
2) The use of ``$\varepsilon!$" is to 
conform with Definition \ref{z6}.
\end{remark}

\noindent
Recall (from \ref{z6})
\begin{definition}
\label{g8}
Let $\tau$ be a vocabulary and $\Delta \subseteq \{\varphi \in
{\mathbb L}(\tau):\varphi = \varphi(\bar x,\bar y)\}$ but $\varphi(\bar x,\bar y) \in \Delta$ means we can add to
$\bar x$ dummy variables.  Let $\lambda > \theta$ (dull otherwise).

A $\tau$-model $M$ is $\langle \lambda,\theta,\varepsilon !,
\Delta \rangle$-saturated
{\underline{when}} \,: if $p \subseteq \{\varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar
a):\varphi(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar y) \in \Delta,\bar a \in {}^{\ell
  g(\bar y)}M\}$ has cardinality $< \lambda$ 
is $(< \theta)$ satisfiable in $M$ {\underline{then}} \, $p$ is realized in $M$. 
\end{definition}

\begin{claim}
\label{g9}

$D$ on a set $I$ and $\theta$-saturated or just
$(\theta,\aleph_0,\varepsilon !,\Delta)$-saturated model $M$, a
cardinality $\mu$ and $\Delta =
{\mathbb L}_{\theta,\theta}(\tau_M)$, the following conditions
are equivalent:
{\medskip\noindent}
\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(a)$]  $D$ is $(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon !,\Delta,T)$-moral ultrafilter on the
  Boolean Algebra ${\mathscr P}(T)$
{\smallskip\noindent}
\item[$(b)$]  if $M \in {\rm Mod}_T$ then $M^I/D$ is 
$(\mu,\theta,\varepsilon !,\Delta,T)$-saturated.
\end{enumerate}
{\medskip\noindent}
2) Similarly for $D$ a filter on a $\theta$-distributive (see \ref{z9}(8))
complete Boolean Algebra ${\mathfrak B}$.
\end{claim}

\begin{PROOF}{\ref{g9}}
Similar to \ref{g10} it actually follows from it because as $D$ is an
ultra-filter, we can start with $M \models T$, expand it to $M^+$ by
adding a predicate to any definable relation and apply \ref{g10} to
$T^+ = {\rm Th}(M^+)$.

a = \{s\}$ and $u = w_s$ we can find a model $M_s$ of $T$ and $\bar
b_{s,\alpha} \in {}^{\ell g(\bar y_\ell)}(M_s)$ for $\alpha \in w_s$
satisying $\bullet$ there.

Now choose $\bar b_{s,\alpha}$ also for $s \in I,\alpha \in \mu
\backslash w_s$, as any sequence of members of $M_s$ of length
$\ell g(\bar y_\alpha)$.  Now for every $\alpha < \mu$ and $j <
\ell g(\bar y_\alpha)$ we define $g_{\alpha,j} \in \prod\limits_{s \in
  I} M_s$ by $g_{\alpha,j}(s) = (\bar b_{s,\alpha})_j$.  

Hence $g_{\alpha,\zeta}/D \in \prod\limits_{s \in I} M_s = N$ and
$\bar b_\alpha = \langle g_{\alpha,\zeta}/D:\zeta < \ell g(\bar
y_\alpha)\rangle \in {}^{\ell g(\bar y_\alpha)}N$ and consider the set
$p = \{\varphi_\alpha(\bar x,\bar b_\alpha):\alpha < \mu\}$.  Is
$p$ a $(< \theta)$-satisfiable type in $N$?  Yes, because if $u \in
[\mu]^{< \theta}$, then $\bold c_u \in D$ and $s \in \bold c_s
\Rightarrow \{\varphi_\alpha(\bar x_{[\varepsilon]},\bar
b_{s,\alpha}):\alpha \in u\}$ is realized in $M_s$, say by $\bar a_s =
\langle a_{s,\zeta}:\zeta < \varepsilon\rangle$; for $s \in I
\backslash \bold c_x,\zeta < \varepsilon$ let $a_{s,j} \in M$ be
arbitrary and let $f_{s,\zeta} \in \prod\limits_{s \in I} M_s$ be
$f_{\alpha,\zeta}(s) = a_{s,j}$.  Easily $\langle f_{\alpha,j}/D:\zeta
< \varepsilon\rangle$ realizes $p$ because $\bold a_u \cap \bold c_u
\in D$.

Next, we apply clause (c) we are assuming so $p(\bar
x_{[\varepsilon]})$ is realized in $N$.
So let $\bar a = \langle a_\zeta:\zeta < 
\varepsilon\rangle \in {}^\varepsilon N$
realize $p$ and let $a_\zeta \in h_\zeta/D$ where $h_\zeta \in
\prod\limits_{s \in I} M_s$ and lastly let
text:
\[
\bold b_u = \{s \in I:M_s \models \varphi_\alpha[\langle
h_\zeta(s):\zeta < \varepsilon\rangle,\bar b_{s,\alpha}] \text{ for
  every } \alpha \in u \text{ and }s \in \bold c_u\}.
\]
